The national completion rate is 64.6%. Visit the 2020 online Census questionnaire to safely and confidentially complete the 2020 Census. The Census takes less than 10 minutes to complete. https://my2020census.gov/

FIRST DAY IN EA: Hooray! It's the first day of school! While the 2020-21 school year has begun in a most unusual way, we celebrate a new opportunity for our students to learn and grow. On August 31, students of all ages, from across the east side of Aurora, logged into their devices, and made remote connections with caring teachers who have been working hard to help their students be successful. Thank you to all our families for your kind words of support and patience, as together we take new steps in learning. With each day, habits will form, and a routine will set in. As we return to learning, may the new school year surprise all of us in big, beautiful ways.
Send your "first day" photos to info@d131.org

CARAVAN FOR COMPLETE COUNT: On July 15, EASD 131 joined local nonprofits and the Aurora Complete Count Committee on a car caravan through our neighborhoods. From there the caravan continued to the Fox Valley Ice Arena in Geneva, where it met a caravan from Elgin. The message? An accurate count of all children is critical for educators and school districts that serve children. Responses from the 2020 Census will drive decisions about the distribution of federally-funded programs for the next 10 years. Census takers will begin going door-to-door to find uncounted households beginning Aug. 11. There is still time to complete online or by mail. As of July 14, Illinois’ self-response rate for completing the 2020 Census is 66.9% while Aurora’s response rate is 68.9%. The national completion rate is 62.1%. Although we are living in stressful times, please visit the 2020 online Census questionnaire to safely and confidentially complete you’re the 2020 Census. The Census will take under 10 minutes to complete. You may also choose to complete by phone or by mail.
https://my2020census.gov/

post_text: RELATIONSHIPS AND THE FIRST YEARS OF LIFE: Relationships are everything to a child, especially in the first years of life. Did you know that positive life experiences stimulate a a young child's brain development? Children with supportive relationships learn to cope with adversity, and demonstrate emotional well-being and confidence. post_text: COUGARS HOST BLACK HISTORY EXPO: On February 27, students at Krug Elementary attended a Black History Expo, in celebration of Black History Month. Special guest author Dr. Willie Etta Wright was on hand, to share stories and songs, and to read her book, "Grandma Mabel, Are You Able?" to students. Our Cougars also visited the gymnasium, where the expo was set up with a variety of activities to choose from. Students had the chance to learn West African dance, play African drums, explore an interactive Underground Railroad, paint a mural, enjoy African face painting, and more. Thank you to Dr. Willie Etta Write, for sharing your stories and energy with students, and special thanks to Krug staff member Chardon Hill and a team of dedicated staff, who helped create this special experience for students!

post_text: EASD 131 CHEER COMPETITION: On February 22, District 131 held its district-wide elementary cheer leading competition at East High. Cheerleading teams from nine schools participated, including Hermes, Johnson, Beaupre, Dietrich, Krug, Barwell, Allen, Fred Rodgers Magnet Academy and Oak Park. The East High varsity cheer team also performed. What a great day of performances for the big crowd of families on hand! For the first time ever, there was a tie for first place! Johnson took second place, coached by Janeen Corbin, followed by Bardwell in third place, coached by Samantha Hagedorn and Noelani Licon. Congratulations to all our winners and participants! And a big thank you to the East High cheer leading squad and their coaches for their support the event!

post_text: CHESS TEAM SUCCESS: Hooray! This year, for the first time ever, the East High Chess Team was named Upstate 8 Conference Tournament champs. The Tomcats took home the 1st Place Trophy at their competition on January 25. Next up was Sectional competition on February 2, where the team registered a 3-1 performance—including a wild, last-second checkmate in Round 4! Our favorite chess crew is now headed back to State competition, where last year they finished 29th out of 128 state-qualifying teams. The state finals will be held Friday and Saturday, February 14-15, at the Peoria Civic Center in Peoria, IL. Congratulations, good luck, and best wishes to our Tomcat Chess Team and Coach Drew Herrmann!

post_text: PLAYERS OF THE WEEK: Wow! For the month of January, not one, but two Tomcats were named "Aurora Beacon News Player of the Week." The first was senior Tatiana Ocasio, East Aurora Ladycats, for the week of January 8. Tatiana made five of six free throws in the final 1:35 against Glenbard South, lifting East Aurora to a 37-33 win in double overtime. The senior guard finished with 11 points and has 1,015 for her high school career. Then for the week of January 22, 2020, Jacques Kelly from the East High boys team was named Aurora Beacon News Player of the Week. Jacques is a junior forward who had 14 points, 11 rebounds and a pair of blocked shots on January 18 to lead East Aurora to a memorable 51-44 win over West Aurora. Way to go, Tatiana and Jacques!

post_text: PASS IN REVIEW: On December 4, the Tomcat Naval Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps (NJROTC) Program held its Annual Pass-In-Review Ceremony at East High. The event included an opening ceremony by the NJROTC Color Guard, performances by the drill team, dance, drum and bugle team, the Knock Out drill, as well as the ceremonial Pass-In-Review by the senior class. The Pass-in-Review is a formal, time-honored ceremony that dates back before the Civil War. It honors cadets’ hard work and dedication. Prior to the public ceremony, Commander Joseph Hankins conducted the annual inspection of the cadets at East Aurora High School during the school day. During the event, the Dedicated Sons LEMC presented a $1,000 donation to the East High NJROTC, in memory of one of their members, Mr. Tommy Lee, who died of liver cancer. Thank you to the Dedicated Sons LEMC for your generosity, and to Lt. Lauren Carthan and all our Navel Science Instructors for their leadership. And congratulations to all our Tomcat NJROTC for a job well done!

post_text: FRENCH HONOR SOCIETY IN SERVICE: On November 23, East High's French Honor Society (FHS) and Advisor Sarah Birdsall paid a visit to Hesed House, to help set up donations and prepare for their upcoming Christmas store. Hesed House coordinators were incredibly impressed with how hard our students worked, and asked when the FHS could return to help out again! Tomcat junior Moises Jimenez, the FHS's community service coordinator, arranged the visit. Way to go, Tomcats!

post_text: PUMAS COMPETE IN MATHEMATICS: On November 16, six students from Fred Rodgers Magnet Academy Math Team participated in the 17th annual Marmion Academy Junior High Mathematics Contest. The students competed in a 20-question individual competition, and then came together to also compete in a 20-question team competition. Get this: FRMA has participated in the Marmion contest for many years, and this year is the first time we have had students place in the top 10 for the individual competition! Congratulations to all our participants, and a big high-five to Gabriel Camacho for placing 6th and to Noe Martinez for placing 4th in the individual competition!

post_text: THANK YOU, SCHOOL BOARD: Today we celebrate our EASD 131 Board of Education, for their commitment and contributions to our schools. They sacrifice a great deal to ensure students have a high quality education system that prepares them for college or career, and allows them to reach their full potential. Clockwise from top left: Board President Annette Johnson; Board Vice President Dan Barreiro; Board Treasurer Kimberly Hatchett; and Board Members Alex Arroyo, Juan Sifuentes, Avis Miller, and Bruce Schubert. Thank you, Board members!

post_text: Did you know that parental involvement in early childhood has been associated with higher reading and math scores, fewer attendance issues, and fewer behavioral problems in students (HiattMichael, 2001). Involvement in school is equally beneficial for parents as well; they are more aware of the educational needs of their children, develop more positive relationships and attitudes towards teachers, and seek higher educational opportunities for their children (Larocque, Kleiman & Darling, 2011). YOU can get involved with us at East Aurora District 131 preschool! We LOVE our Tiny Tomcat Parents and enjoy sharing learning experiences like this trip to the Morton Arboretum. Preschool is FREE to district 131 families! Please bring your child's birth certificate in to the Early Childhood Center at 278 East Indian Trail, Monday through Friday, 7:45-4:00 pm to get started. Children must be three years old and do not have to be toilet trained to participate. For questions or more information, please call Patty at the Early Childhood Center, (630) 299-7460.

post_text: BOARD LEADER RECOGNIZED: Congratulations to District 131 Board of Education President Annette Johnson, who was recognized by the Marie Wilkinson Food Pantry (MWFP) at their annual Sunday Brunch Fundraiser, “Fill the Bowls” on October 27 at Gaslite Manor Banquets. Johnson was honored with the Pantry’s annual “Leadership Award” for her efforts in developing a food rescue program in East Aurora District 131, and for helping to open the Marie Wilkinson Food Pantry’s east side location, now located at East High. MWFP Board President Ms. Theodia Gillespie presented Johnson with the award. Our Tomcats were well-represented at the fundraiser, as East High students from the Culinary Team joined more than 20 Fox Valley restaurants serving delicious food to over 400 guests at the event. Students served crepes and strawberry kale smoothies. The East High’s NJROTC cadets were also on hand, assisting with clearing tables and helping guests enjoy the day. What a wonderful day for our District and the community!

post_text: SHARING A MEAL, SHARING COMMUNITY: At Johnson Elementary, 2nd grade dual language students have been studying communities the past several weeks. In their most recent story, the characters cooked a dinner that brings different members of a community together. On October 11, as an extension, the 2nd grade students recreated the meal from the story by making a cheese quesadilla! Mmmm! But there's more: the students' families donated extra ingredients and, after cooking the meal at school, the students will be boxing up the extra items to be taken to Hesed House. After school, Johnson teachers Brooke Shanley, Isabel Jorjorian, Carolina Barrios, Pedro Rosales, and Saul Olivas, went to Hesed House and used the items to cook dinner for the residents that evening. Nice job, Jaguar students, staff and families!

Our friends from the Aurora Public Library were on hand to tell families how they can get a library card. There was even a swimming pool filled with fish, with words written on them! Families took home baggies of donated snacks and desserts gathered by Mr. Adler. Special thanks to all who helped make the evening successful for our students and families, and thank you to Mr. Peterson and his team for a very successful and engaging night with our families!

post_text: NATIONAL WALK TO SCHOOL DAY: Krug Elementary was one of several schools that celebrated "National Walk to School Day" on October 2. Principal Noah Little and staff welcomed special guests from the Montgomery Fire Department and paramedics, the Montgomery Police Department, and City of Aurora Deputy Mayor Chuck Nelson and Office Manager Maria Lindsay. The rain held off just enough for students, staff, parents, and special guests to began their day with a brisk walk around Krug Park. What fun! Walk to School Day promotes creating safe routes for walking and bicycling, and emphasizes the importance of issues such as increasing physical activity among children, pedestrian safety, traffic congestion, concern for the environment, and building connections between families, schools and the broader community. Great job, Krug Cougars!
